important_phrase: Areas affected by drought conditions expanded in the District since the last report
Payrolls expanded slowly, and businesses continued to report challenges filling positions
Many District companies continued to report adding to headcounts, albeit modestly
Small businesses indicated continued difficulty in obtaining financing and noted funding some expansion with cash
Finished inventory levels were reported to be slightly lower than the previous report
Most builders and brokers reported home sales were flat to up slightly and buyer traffic increased relative to one-year earlier
Year-to-date Mississippi casino gaming revenues increased compared with the same period last year
Contacts cite very limited, if any, upward pressure on prices and say they plan to raise wages only modestly
The firm with slowing sales growth says they reduced inventory as a result of the lowered outlook
Investment sales volume remains high in Boston and Portland and moderately strong in Hartford
Apparel, furniture, and items related to home improvement are selling well
Hog and cattle prices were lower
Gains in business spending were moderate, but growth in consumer spending, manufacturing production, and construction and real estate was slower
Those firms reporting price increases were more likely to cite stronger demand or increased pricing power than higher costs
Mortgage loan demand increased marginally and origination quality remained strong
The pace of hiring also remained moderate, but hiring plans slowed some
Residential rents increased modestly, while home sales, home prices, and home affordability were little changed
Vehicle transaction prices continued to rise, though at a slower pace, as manufacturers increased incentives
Natural gas production remains at elevated levels
Overall, input and finished-goods prices were steady
Consumer lending expanded modestly over the period, with activity concentrated in auto lending and home equity products
Payrolls increased slightly over the period
Construction payrolls expanded at a moderate pace over the period for field and office jobs
Payrolls were fairly stable over the period, but dealers indicated that labor markets are tight, putting upward pressure on wages
The latest estimates for Texas cotton production came in lower than expected due to weak yields
Price pressures remained subdued and employment held steady or increased
Employment in most industries held steady or increased
Contacts cited recent monetary policy actions, financial market turbulence, and low oil prices as factors that have increased uncertainty
Accounting services demand remained robust, although one contact noted a slower pipeline of construction-related work
Contacts in Houston noted slower buyer traffic and weakness in sales of higher-priced new homes
Outlooks were mostly positive, with retailers expecting flat or stronger growth in the fourth quarter and auto dealers anticipating the normal seasonal strength at yearend
Farm income expectations remained subdued as low crop prices persisted and livestock prices declined since the last survey period
Energy firms reported moderate declines in activity, and farm income remained subdued due to weak prices
Retail wages rose at a slightly higher rate, while restaurants and transportation wages increased at a slower pace
Demand for agricultural loans declined slightly
Both durable and nondurable goods production continued to decline, although some nondurable production such as plastics, chemicals, and food improved slightly
Residential real estate sales and home prices, led by strong gains in Colorado, rose moderately compared to the previous survey period, and inventories declined slightly
Expectations for future sales slowed modestly but remained positive, and inventory levels were expected to be unchanged
Wile growing conditions were good, the income outlook for agricultural producers remained weak
The Ninth District economy grew moderately since the last report
Price pressures remained subdued
Professional services grew modestly
Commercial construction continued to expand moderately
Consumer spending grew modestly
Agriculture conditions were mixed
Consumer spending grew moderately in the latest reporting period
The New York, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, St Louis, Minneapolis, and Dallas Districts indicated that employment was up modestly to moderately
Credit conditions were mixed but mostly improved
On balance, goods transportation services softened since the previous report
Residential real estate activity has generally improved since the last report, with almost all Districts reporting rising prices and sales volume
Most Districts indicated that non-auto retail sales expanded at a modest or moderate rate
Multi-family residential construction has been increasingly robust, whereas commercial construction has slowed
Small to medium sized banks in the District report increased demand for commercial mortgages but little change in demand for other types of loans
Manufacturers report that selling prices are flat to declining modestly, while input prices remain generally stable
Across other parts of the District--Long Island, northern New Jersey, and the Lower Hudson Valey--home prices are generally stable or rising modestly
Retailers report mixed results for August and September
Homebuilders reported slight growth overall; flat for most, but stronger than before for a few
However, several staffing contacts indicated difficulties recruiting for low-skill positions
Banking contacts in most parts of the District described a steadily growing economy with little sign of inflation
Firms continued to cite concerns about the strong dollar; however, a contact at one firm noted that the firm was building inventories of commodity inputs while prices were low
Overall, Third District homebuilders have reported a slight improvement since the last Beige Book
An improving economy and continued good weather were cited as factors
Coal prices were unchanged
Price increases slowed
Wge increases slowed in the service sector, while manufacturing wages rose moderately and the average workweek shortened
However, commercial loan demand rose modestly
Tourism strengthened moderately in recent weeks
Commercial real estate activity increased moderately since the previous report
Retail sales grew at a slower pace since the previous Beige Book
Agricultural activity expanded slightly during the reporting period
Overall price inflation appeared to firm slightly, and upward wage pressures increased further
Upward wage pressures grew moderately across the District
Lending activity grew modestly over the reporting period
Semiconductor sales slowed slightly
Permits for new residential projects grew modestly, although shortages of available land continued to constrain new construction somewhat
Demand for business and consumer services expanded further
Year-to-date coal production is currently , percent below last year's level
Contacts across many industries reported increased hiring difficultly
Loan growth slowed somewhat relative to prior quarters but remains in positive territory and above the national growth rate
Manufacturing activity has improved at a modest pace since our last report
That said, contacts expect a steady improvement through year-end
However, some retailers noted a slight slowdown in activity during the final weeks of summer
